Authors:
Marie Fougere-Danezan, Simon Joly, Anne Bruneau, Xinfen
Gao, Li-Bing Zhang
Title:
Major lineages, biogeography and polyploidy in wild
roses
Keywords:
Rosa, phylogeny, taxonomy, biogeography, ancestral area
reconstruction, divergence time, allopolyploidy, hybridization
Abstract:
The genus Rosa L. (150 to 200 species) is widely
distributed throughout the temperate and subtropical habitats from the
northern hemisphere to tropical Asia, with only one tropical African
species. In order to better understand the evolution of roses, we study
infrageneric relationships with respect to conventional taxonomy,
discuss the extent of allopolyploidization and infer macroevolutionary
processes that have led to the current distribution of the genus.
Phylogenetic relationships among species of the genus Rosa were
reconstructed using sequences from three plastid markers as well as from
one nuclear marker, which was used to identify putative allopolyploids
and infer their possible origins. The chloroplast phylogeny was used to
estimate divergence times and reconstruct ancestral areas. Most
subgenera and sections defined by traditional taxonomy were not
monophyletic. However, several clades were partly consistent with
currently recognized sections. Allopolyploidy seems to have played an
important role in stabilizing intersectional hybrids. Biogeographic
analyses suggest that Asia played a central role as a genetic reservoir
in the evolution of the genus Rosa. Directions for a new sectional
classification of the genus Rosa are proposed, and our analyses provide
an evolutionary framework for future studies on this notoriously
difficult genus.
